She knew what was beckoning: the lower bunk in my childhood bedroom in Newark. We'd even had sex on it once. And it was a thing to be pitied and avoided.
Lindy. I really thought I had it in me to do something. --I wasn't getting around it, but it was fucking there. And now, I, ah...

All the way home she was back on my mind ... Melissa.
She'd been so smart. Smarter than anyone around her. And oh, how she loved to provoke people...
I thought, by now, she'd be curing cancer, directing movies, running for the Senate...
...vomiting on his boss' desk during a presentation...
... or stealing his dying Aunt's Percocet.
But there was no link between my Melissa and this upstate Melissa dumped, cold-calling people from her living room.
40 long blocks later I was "home."
Well. There was less than nothing to lose.
I didn't want to see anybody.
Tuesday.
Just tell him-
I suddenly had extra reason to get away from her. I had thoughtlessly ingested a substance.
I had gotten remarkably little information from Vernon about what this drug would do.
...What if it was a hallucinogen...
And then... I felt it.
Levels more, layers more, 3-D more... galactically more. But the same. Just the depth and beauty...
What's wrong?
"I was blind but now I see."
You don't like me, and I don't blame you -- you see a schlumpy energy- sucking defeated sack of shit sponging off your husband.
Something wrong at school?
People who aren't don't usually carry dry, academic constipated out of print books about Dorothea Lange.
I just saw the book--
I've seen it before.
...sitting on the couch of a T.A. I was trying to make, waiting for her to come back out of the bathroom...
Somehow, my unconscious had served that up... a memory I'd never even recorded. Or was it there the whole time... and all I needed... was the access?
Vern was right. This was no recreational drug.
If you're writing a paper, that's not the book I'd use.
Cal Berkeley has her oral history.
We'd really worked on her paper, too. In 45 minutes it was a polished gem. She was pleased.
Happy and sore, I returned home.
... But it couldn't be my home, could it? Who would live like this?
The next morning, I sent a little probe down into my brain. No surge of brilliance came up to greet me.
But something remained.
No.
Yes.
Three pages. That's all you have to read. If you read them in the next hour, and you don't want to keep reading I'll give back the advance.
But how would I finish? It was "enhanced" Eddie who displayed all that brilliance. Not me.
Yeah?
Vern! It's Eddie.
Vern -- last night 90 pages just wrote themselves! I totally chucked the novel I pitched them --I suddenly SAW, Vern, how this whole societal economic class struggle --
Yeah. That stuff's amazing.
What's... um... what's it called?

Okay, so what did we have here?
Yes. Definitely.
Uh... sure.
It was amazing how quickly it all slotted back into place...
..the dealer-client dynamic......
...the easy sacrificing of dignity for the guaranteed return of a dime bag, or a gram, or in this case a little pill that was going to cost me a month's rent.

is no tough guy, and sweat springs to his brow. He starts shaking... then, seized with horror that they might still be in here, he edges to the bedroom. We hear THE POUNDING OF HIS HEART as he peeks in...
Yes... I... I need to report a murder. Eddie. Morgan. --Edward J.

At least you got your last meal.

Heyheyhey! I'm the one that called you!
... No, ex-wife's brother. I just ran into him on the street and he invited me up to, you know...

But I knew, when his attention wandered to something more pressing, that he was going to let me go.

Probably not. Hopefully not.
Back on MDT, it was obvious what I should do.
Vern's cash...
...combined with an unprecedented surge of motivation...
...enabled me to finish the book in four days.
A tablet a day... kept the torpor away. And what I could do with my day... was limitless.
I now had cultural appetites.
Learned to read music in a week...
The only cloud was the nagging feeling I was being followed.
The focal point of my existence quickly became... protecting my stash.
I had a new, improved game.
Which means a prosaic author's work rests on a foundation of acclaim-
So you're saying praise and fame are unrelated to achievement, that the greatest hits CD cannot possibly contain good songs? That Shakespeare's catchiness belies mediocrity?
Well, then I'd guess you'd rather not hear about what I, personally, think could launch a thousand ships?
And it wasn't just women. I was, for the first time in my life, a presence...
Of course, all this seemed to work better with people I didn't know...
...so, Mom, your 401 K is totally mis-invested -- these guys are have done ONLY the most Pliocine era fundamental analysis and paid no attention to eye candy psychology surrounding the stock --
Okay, remember when I explained default flops? Did any of that stick?
CDS's? CDO's CBO's?
--Sure you get a short term spike, but wouldn't that rapid expansion devalue the stock completely in two years?
Against aggressive over-expansion?
We're wired to overreach -- you look at history, I mean, all the countries that ruled the world?
Hey, I want in on it!
Thank you so much.
But Vern's cash was low. And it takes cash to make cash...
But it takes cash to make cash...
I'd like to re-negotiate my advance.
This isn't going to work.
Yes, but I now see that writing, as a profession, is for marginalized whiners not fit for anything else.
No, I mean it, look at the life.

Oh, if you're good, there's some remuneration, eventually, after paperbacks, but at best your career'll be oozing along like a snail, a few thousand more copies, whoop-dee-doo, you're "developing a readership," -- for what? So you can end up in Phoenix on a Saturday night reading from your own work at some holdout indie book store to a bored audience of ten? --Half of them there for the wine and cheese?
I don't think any goal will be really achievable, Mark, until I'm sitting on a large pile of cash.
I would have to start very, very small... in a down market. No one was making money. But no one had MDT...
Armed with Vern's last 800 dollars, I made 4000 in a day.
It was too slow.
Why not?
Because I quintupled my money four days in a row.
It's not luck.
You think?
And that's a problem for you because--?
I won't. And what if I do? You think I keep detailed records of my investors? You'll have your money back long before they figure out what happened.
My new friend, Kevin Doyle, showed me how you could leverage two and a half times your cash at a day-
But not for the big fat defense contract he bribed his way into.
I'd heard the old metaphors about the stock market: it was a collective nervous system, a global brain, a numerical representation of the will of God...
Whatever it was, I was jacked in, booted up - my mind was living tissue inside the greater, functioning whole.
The word quickly got out.
Four job offers... my bank, raising my line of credit... a reporter...
All my new friends.
And finally, Kevin Doyle, trying to sound casual.
Apparently he does.
Self-improvement month. Someone gave me a wake-up call.
Why? It stuck, didn't it?

Her place...

Nothing.

You want to push that button? I'll show you my silos if you show me yours.

I don't think I can keep this.

I was like, down the hatch. And it was amazing. I read Brian Greene's The Elegant Universe in 45 minutes and understood it. My work rate increased... just, insanely, overnight. My boss started to hate me -- they offered me his job. And then I got scared.
I'm not stupid. I mean, nobody can keep up that level of mental activity and not crash. I stopped taking it.

I got sick. Headaches, throwing up... I went back to Vernon to see if I maybe shouldn't take another hit, or half a hit, and then he told me about... about the people who were dying. One guy didn't die, but he's a vegetable, his mother has to sponge him down every day...
How much have you been taking, Eddie?
Well, maybe they've worked out the bugs. Maybe... maybe this isn't the same batch...
You're off it right now, aren't you?
Are you getting a headache?

Well, I didn't take more. And I didn't die. But after a while I found I couldn't concentrate on anything for longer than ten minutes. I missed deadlines. I got lazy... and slow... put on weight... the magazine let me go.
That was two years ago, and I haven't been the same since. I can't read any more -- I mean, the fucking New York Post?
